ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

BISHAN WEST ESTATE
(Change of name)


    1. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for National Development whether a decision has been made to change the name of Bishan West Estate to Sin Ming Garden Estate and, if so, when the change will be implemented.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the name of Bishan West Estate will be changed to Sin Ming Garden Estate. The new name will apply from 15th April 1988.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson): Sir, will the Ministry make a press release so that all the residents in Bishan West Estate will know about this change?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Yes, Mr Speaker.

Column: 1587

HDB MULTI-TIER FAMILY HOUSING SCHEME
(Cases of abuse)


    2. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for National Development how many cases of abuse have been detected under the 3-tier family privilege scheme introduced by the Housing and Development Board and how have they been dealt with.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, the Multi-tier Family Housing Scheme was introduced in May 1982. On allocation, the multi-tier family must stay together in the flat for eight years before the flat can be sold in the open market. Within the eight years, if the parents or grandparents are found to be not staying in the flat without valid reasons, the applicant would have breached a condition under the scheme. The HDB would then recover the flat to prevent abuse of the scheme.

    As at 29th February 1988, of the 12,500 flats allocated under the Multi-tier Family Scheme, the HDB recovered 18 flats or 0.14%. Out of these 18 flats, 17 units were returned voluntarily to the HDB because

Column: 1588

the parents and the married children did not wish to continue staying together. In the remaining case, the applicant abused the scheme because he did not report to the HDB that the multi-family structure no longer existed. HDB recovered the flat when the Board found this out subsequently.

AYER RAJAH/ROCHESTER PARK AREA
(Concept plan)


    The following question stood in the name of Encik Abbas Abu Amin -

    3. To ask the Minister for National Development (a) whether the Housing and Development Board has finalised plans for the extension and development of Ayer Rajah Estate and, if so, whether the HDB will consider building 5-room or Executive flats there; and (b) if the housing programme has been finalised, whether he will give details of it, indicating also how the traffic flow in the Estate will be modified and linked with the nearby Buona Vista Mass Rapid Transit station.

     Mr Speaker: Encik Abbas.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): Question 3, Sir.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry is in the process of preparing a new Concept Plan for the Ayer Rajah/Rochester Park area. The Plan covers the area bounded by Commonwealth Avenue West, Clementi Road, Pasir Panjang Road and Alexandra Road. The HDB Ayer Rajah Estate is seen as an integral part of this area.

    In preparing the plan, the planners will try to preserve the amenities of the existing developments and will also propose new developments that will complement the residential, institutional and recreational facilities in the area. Better quality housing and new infrastructure will be provided. An efficient transportation system will be planned to link up with the Buona Vista MRT Station.

    Since the plan is not finalised, I am unable to provide specific details on the number and type of residential units that would be incorporated in the plan.

"LEASE-A-DENTAL CLINIC" SCHEME
(Progress)


    6. Dr Ho Tat Kin asked the Acting Minister for Health what is the progress made by his Ministry's "Lease-A-Dental Clinic" scheme; and whether this scheme has been able to provide better dental care at a lower cost to the people.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, the Lease-A-Dental Clinic Scheme was introduced in 1984. So far, 11 dental clinics with a total of 25 dental chairs have been leased. The Scheme has met its objectives. It is providing young dental officers with the opportunity to gain commercial experience before they venture into their own private practice. So far, 44 dental officers have participated in the Scheme.

    The dentists operating the leased dental clinics are providing a more personalized service. They spend more time on each patient and also offer a much wider range of dental services such as crowns and bridges. Waiting time has also been reduced.

    As for the cost of treatment, it is not possible for the dentists operating the leased dental clinics to charge the same fees as the subsidized Government dental clinics. However, their fees are generally lower than the fees charged by other private dentists providing a similar high degree of personal service.

    Head R -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [28th March, 1988],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head R of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Mr Lim Boon Heng].

    Question again proposed.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, when we adjourned yesterday, the Member for Leng Kee was clarifying what he meant by "factor intensity". I was not quite clear about the meaning. What he explained was whether we tend to allow more foreign workers to work in capital-intensive industries and less in labour-intensive industries. My answer is no. We allow foreign workers in each approved company in the manufacturing sector up to 50% of its workforce. If a company employs 400 workers, it can employ up to 200 foreign workers. So there is a corresponding relationship to the workforce. The more labour-intensive industries would tend to have more foreign workers.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Yuhua): Sir, I would like to speak on the use of contract workers.

    In the past year, feedback from our unions indicate that there is an increase in the use of contract workers. This practice is not limited to one or two areas but appears to be more widespread. At present, contract workers are employed in the shipbuilding and shiprepairing industry, the construction industry, the electrical and electronics industry and even in statutory boards and Government departments.

    We can understand that in some cases, the use of contract workers is beneficial to both employers as well as full-time permanent employees. This is because when there is a downturn, retrenchment of full-time permanent employees can be made a measure of last resort. However, there appears to be other reasons for the use of contract workers. Some companies which have been unable to recruit sufficient workers have resorted to labour supply contractors to meet their shortage.

Column: 1592



    Other companies appear to use contract workers because of lower costs. Some of them do not pay CPF or provide medical and other fringe benefits. Because of this, they attract workers by offering higher take-home pay.

    I am concerned with the abuses that go with the use of contract workers. Contract workers are not required to conform to the basic rules of the companies. They are not required to record their attendance with the punch-card system which apply to other employees. In cases of misbehaviour, they are not subjected to the company's disciplinary regulations. These differences must and have affected the morale of the direct employees. If the practice becomes more widespread, workers in general will also be adversely affected.

    It is therefore necessary for the Ministry of Labour to monitor the situation and check abuse. We should also be concerned that the use of contract workers will have an adverse effect on skills. There will be little incentive for employers to provide training for such workers.

    I am also surprised that even statutory boards and Government departments are increasingly using contract workers. Some of them may be doing so to circumvent the directive of the Ministry of Finance to trim the public sector staffing strength.

    The NTUC received a complaint that one statutory board actually pressurized long-serving employees to transfer to another subsidiary on contract terms. This is unfair treatment. I would strongly urge the Ministry of Labour to look into the matter urgently.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, I would like to thank the Member for Yuhua for bringing up this problem.

    The use of contract workers has been a common practice for some time now, especially in the construction and shipyard industries. The reason is that it is a convenient means of meeting the cyclical demand pattern of these particular industries.

    What is new is that they are used recently by some electronics firm and, as the Member has just told us, maybe also by some Government departments.

Column: 1593

Following complaints, my Ministry has been studying the practice more closely and we are still looking into the matter. Our studies show that it is not entirely true that all contract workers do not have protection. Many are paid CPF contributions and other statutory benefits as stipulated in the Employment Act. However, they are unlikely to be given any retrenchment benefits when their services are no longer needed.

    In many instances, contract workers are direct employees of labour suppliers. The labour suppliers act as the employers. The workers could be either local workers or foreign workers. They are deployed to work at the premises of the labour suppliers' clientele which are usually shipyards, construction firms and, lately, also some electronics firms, and maybe even garment firms. These workers are normally daily-rated employees and, like regular workers, enjoy annual leave, sick leave, public holiday pay and so on as well as transport and accommodation provided by the labour suppliers. Many labour suppliers also make CPF contributions for local contract workers and pay the levy for foreign workers to the Government.

    However, I understand the Member's concern. I think my Ministry is equally anxious to make sure that there are no abuses and that the use of contract workers is not a means to circumvent the Government's policies, for example, on controlling foreign workers or to avoid paying the levy, and so forth. We also want to make sure that the workers are adequately protected, that their interests are protected.

    As for the case of the Government department involved, I think the Member should bring up the particulars to the relevant Ministry, and maybe the Minister for Finance, for his attention.

     Mr Lim Boon Heng (Kebun Baru): Sir, two weeks ago the Member for Ayer Rajah introduced in this House a Report supporting the use of CPF funds for the tertiary education of CPF members' children. I think it was a well-documented report and a persuasive document. Certainly the issue

Column: 1594

is a popular one. We all know it through discussions with our grassroots leaders in our constituencies and it is quite natural for us to come to this House to press the case.

    In our GPC for Labour, I was against pursuing the matter after the Minister's comprehensive reply to this House last year and also in other forums. So I thought to pursue the issue would be like flogging a dead horse. However, the issue is such a popular one that I acceded to a re-examination of this issue in my GPC.

    My GPC is divided on the issue. There is a majority view, however, that the proposal should be supported. My GPC members would therefore speak their own minds. I have had further reflections on the subject and must regrettably tell my friend, the Member for Ayer Rajah, that I am not in favour of allowing CPF to be used for education. Let me explain why.

    As Members of this House, we should not merely articulate popular feeling on an issue. Certainly we should to so. But we should give our considered opinion, our own individual considered opinion on the issue. What the people want may not always be the right thing to do.

    Take the case of allowing investment of CPF funds in shares and gold. What was the origin of this idea? I recollect that at a time of high interest rates, the CPF interest rate was fixed, I believe, at 6ª%; people were unhappy. They said that the CPF interest rate ought to be higher. Many said that they could do better if they were allowed to invest the money themselves and no amount of explanation - that we should take a long-term view, that we should consider the difficulties of investing large sums of money - would satisfy the public. And if my recollection is right, Members of this House pressed the case of the public very assiduously to the Minister for Labour. So the Government acceded and pegged the CPF interest rate to the average rate of the four big banks. Government also allowed CPF holders to invest their CPF money within certain limits.

    Then what happened? When the stock market crashed, what do we hear? Some who lost their monies blamed the Government. In fact, I recollect that there were

Column: 1595

people outside who said, "You know the risks. Why did you allow me to lose my money investing in the stock exchange?" I agree people are now wiser about investment in stocks and shares. The lesson is learnt that it is not easy to invest money. And the Government's original policy on CPF interest rate was not wrong. In fact, now I think many would have preferred that we had left the CPF interest rate where it was, at 6ª%.

    Once CPF was allowed for investment in what is described as the Stock Exchange Casino, the arguments for allowing the use of CPF for tertiary education became stronger.

    The fact that we have also introduced the Minimum Sum Scheme has weakened somewhat the Government's case for not allowing the use of CPF for education because it is very easy to argue that investment in education is sounder and more valuable than investment in stocks and shares. I have my reservations because CPF for education means different things to different people. We are talking about tertiary education here. But in the homes of the lower income group and among workers, they are talking about CPF for primary education and secondary education, not tertiary education.

    If we allow CPF for tertiary education, then on what basis are we to deny the low-income parents the right to use his CPF to put his children through school? To him it is far more important that he should be allowed to use his CPF savings in order to ensure that his child or children get through primary and secondary school. In our dialogue with trade unionists, we have been from time to time urged to ask the Government to allow them to pay from the CPF the bills which they are unable or find difficulty to pay. For example, PUB bills. Have we not, as Members of Parliament, received appeals from our constituents to help them obtain release of their CPF funds to pay for PUB arrears, rent arrears, service and conservancy charge arrears? How are we to explain to them that we can allow the high income earners to use the CPF savings for education of their children but not to allow the poor the use of the CPF for schooling of their children?

Column: 1596



    I think we will be opening Pandora's box if we proceed with the suggestion. More requests will be made. More items will be loaded on to the CPF. It reminds me of the loading of the social security systems in many Western countries. To fund the increased demand, more taxes have to be raised but Western governments find they cannot easily raise taxes as the effect of raising taxes has other consequences. So some of the governments in the West have begun to try to unscramble the mess that they are in, to simplify their social security systems. In our case, if we proceed on that road, one bright fresh young Member of Parliament will at a future date be telling us in this House the urgency of reforming the CPF.

    Is there a pressing need here that we cannot meet through other means? After all, what is the problem? The problem is that people want to have funds to put their children through university. It is only 10-20% who may be in a position to use their CPF funds for sending their children to university. So I think there are other options available. Let us tackle the problem where it is, that is, the availability of funds for putting their children through university. One possibility is to encourage young parents to plan ahead. Have children, plan ahead for your children, set aside some savings regularly so that when they reach the age to go to university there is a sum for them to meet their expenses. They could set up this savings account in the names of their children. There is also another alternative, and that is, to buy insurance policies for the education of children. Many of these policies are available now, including NTUC Income. For those whose children are already grown up, the time is past to talk about buying insurance policy or saving up. But what is the alternative? They can take up loans. We have a tertiary education loan scheme implemented last year. I was in the United Kingdom recently and they are talking about a loan scheme for their own education system. From what I understand, in our own loan scheme, so far the number of people who have to take loans is very small. Maybe the Minister could let us know how many people have taken loans and what amounts have actually been taken up. But the amount has been

Column: 1597

very small. Therefore, it shows that there is no real difficulty of parents to send their children to university.

    I hope that Members who favour using CPF for education will reconsider their position. But I do not think the Member for Ayer Rajah would take "No" for an answer easily. It is not in his nature and I would be very disappointed if he did. So I hope he will say his piece, listen to the views of other Members, the reply of the Minister and, if he is still not convinced, then go back, take a re-look at the issue, then come back again to this House next year if he is still persuaded that we should allow the use of CPF funds for tertiary education.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong (Cairnhill): Sir, I am afraid I do not agree with my Chairman of the GPC as I will be speaking on CPF for education.

    Sir, the CPF was established by legislation in July 1985 with the aim of providing financial security for wage earners in their old age. Although old-age security remains the main objective of the CPF, it also has schemes that enable members to use their CPF savings for many purposes, such as to buy flats from HDB and Mindef, for home protection insurance, to invest in approved residential properties, to invest in approved commercial properties, to meet hospitalization expenses for themselves and their dependants, and to invest in shares and in gold. Since the CPF is working out more schemes for public benefit, it should seriously consider a CPF scheme to pay for education expenses.

    Sir, education is an investment for the future. Since CPF monies can be used for so many forms of investment, including shares and gold, it is difficult to justify to the public why CPF cannot be used for the education of our children, especially for tertiary education. Education expenses can be classified into two categories: (a) for local education, and (b) for overseas education.

    As nominal fees only are charged for primary and secondary education locally, Singaporeans have no financial problems in sending their children for such education. The problem lies mainly in tertiary

Column: 1598

education, which is expensive, especially for household incomes of less than $1,500 per month. Currently, university fees in Singapore are at $2,000 per year for an Arts degree, $2,400 per year for a Science degree, and $3,900 per year for a Medical degree.

    According to the CPF 1985 Annual Report, there are 717,817 or 80.7% of active CPF members as at 31st December 1985 drawing salaries of $1,499 and below. These will be the people whose children will benefit if CPF funds can be used for tertiary education in Singapore.

    For overseas education, fees are very much higher and the Minister should seriously consider the use of CPF monies even for overseas education. There is, of course, the danger that some of the overseas graduates may prefer to work overseas for a few years before returning to Singapore and the parents may not be able to depend on them for support in their old age.

    For this reason, may I suggest to the Minister to consider allowing CPF members to use their own CPF for higher education. Many Singaporeans today are keen to acquire a second degree, especially after they have worked for a few years. The Government should encourage Singaporeans to upgrade themselves by using their own CPF to study for higher professional qualifications. These are older and more mature Singaporeans and are very likely to return to Singapore immediately after their overseas education. As a security measure, for all monies withdrawn the beneficiary can sign an undertaking with the CPF Board to return the amount to the account holder, once he is gainfully employed, through monthly deductions from his own CPF account. There is strong grassroots demand for the use of CPF for education and I hope the Minister will reconsider this issue.

     Encik Abbas Abu Amin (Pasir Panjang): Sir, the various measures introduced by the Government, including the CPF cut, to overcome the recession in 1985 and 1986 were clearly understood by our workers. They have no objection to the new wage policy on wage restraint and wage reform. They have accepted wage standstill for two years now. The workers have

Column: 1599

accepted all the measures knowing that they are temporary measures to increase the competitiveness and to improve the marketability of goods and services. All the sacrifices, the concerted efforts and other concrete measures taken by the Government have revived our economy.

    Now, the question which is always in the minds of our workers is: when will the CPF rate be restored and by what percentage? Even though the Minister has given the assurance that the CPF rate will be reviewed after the first quarter of 1988, the workers feel that the objectives of wage restraint and CPF cut for two years have been successfully achieved and therefore the temporary measures should not be taken longer than necessary.

    While measures such as wage restraint and wage reforms are long-term strategies, the Government should consider gradually increasing the CPF rate so as to assist our workers in having sufficient savings to service their HDB flats' monthly instalments and increase savings for old age requirements. This is indeed a test of trust and confidence. The workers cooperated with the Government for two years and made the necessary sacrifices. Now that the economy has recovered and the two-year period is over, the Government should therefore honour its part of the bargain. I am sure the workers will understand and continue to give further cooperation in the future should further sacrifices are needed to overcome impending national crisis.

    Finally, I would like also to ask the Minister whether a definite plan has been made on the implementation of the long-term CPF rates of contribution, especially on the various steps to be taken to gradually reduce the CPF contribution for older workers, ie, those in the 55-60 years age group and 60-65 years age group.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): Sir, like the Chairman of the GPC for Labour, I rise to express similar views. It seems rather unfair that the Member for Ayer Rajah who has done a good job of putting up a very good report is now not able to speak up first on this particular amendment. My name was included in his report as I raised at one time a supplementary question to the Minister to see if he will allow CPF to

Column: 1600

be used for a member's own educational needs. At that time, I was sympathetic towards the idea. I was also trying to test the resolve of the Minister to see how firm was his stand on not allowing CPF to be used for education.

    Sir, CPF for Education is a very popular issue, as the Chairman of the GPC on Labour has just said. But it will also raise many more questions and problems than answers if CPF is allowed for educational purpose. Therefore, I will like to assure the Minister that he has my full support if he stands firm on this issue. If there is a shortage of places in our University I think the CPF is the wrong place to look for solutions. Sir, in this Chamber, on the few occasions that I spoke on the subject of CPF, I have argued for caution and reasoned why we must be very careful in handling the question of CPF, especially on how it may be used.

    When the CPF investment scheme was discussed, I argued against it because I felt that there was no need for the scheme as it will raise several new issues. As a result of Black Monday in October - the big share market drop - I am sure Members have heard of investors who regretted the Government's implementation of this scheme, although I am not so sure that they blamed the Government. I am not so sure that they will blame the Government for it.

    I have also at one time argued for the reactivation of the Special Account. My main point for the reactivation of the Special Account was that some liquid funds should be locked up in the CPF. Too much money has been channelled into housing and investments. The Special Account,or more liquidity in the CPF, serves many purposes. It can serve as a buffer - a device for us to adjust when we have economic problems. It will also come in very useful in the event of a major world-wide economic or financial disaster or disorder.

    CPF for educational purpose means many things to many people. Education is a very emotionally-charged issue, foremost of which is the question of what level of education should be supported by the use of CPF funds. If we allow it for university education, then we are denying many other members whose children may be able to get only professional qualifications

or diplomas. These - I want to emphasize - are all meant for old-age financial security.

Risks can be spread by having a diversified portfolio of investments. To preserve the entire CPF savings for the member's old-age needs, it must be possible to sell the investments and return the money to his CPF account.
